title.narrative: 1.3 ROLLOUT COMMON ACCOUNTABILITY AFFECTED POPULATIONS APPROACH.

mailing-address.narrative: UNICEF House 3 United Nations Plaza New York New York 10017 USA

title.narrative: UNICEF Contract Awards through the UN Global Marketplace
Office of Emergency Programmes 2018 Annual Report
UNICEF Tender Notices through the UN Global Marketplace

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

description.narrative: Major progress achieved in 2018 with the adoption by Regional and HQ Directors in May 2018 of the Business Case for scaling up AAP in UNICEF, which include a roadmap with a results framework, and sets the strategic direction for the period 2018-2021. | Status: | As-of Date:

title.narrative: # of HAC COs supported (remote, mission, learning, and/or surge) to systematically use feedback & complaint mechanisms to inform corrective action to be taken by relevant UNICEF senior management/HCTs

target.value: 2021:20 HAC COs systematically use feedback & complaint mechanisms to inform corrective action to be taken by relevant UNICEF senior management/HCTs

title.narrative: An agreed organization-wide framework for AAP in humanitarian programming is adopted and disseminated throughout UNICEF, and with UNICEF-led clusters and AoRs

baseline.value: A draft organization-wide framework is under development, but not yet adopted, and requires additional guidance and tools

target.value: 2021:AAP is fully mainstreamed in all UNICEF programmes

actual.value: 2019:Endorsed AAP Business Case has set the strategic direction for scaling up AAP in UNICEF and has triggered significant momentum across all Regions, Divisions and increasingly Country Offices

title.narrative: # of activated UNICEF-led clusters and AoRs and/or sector coordination mechanisms supported (remote, missions, learning, and/or surge) to integrate common AAP approaches to improve quality, coverage and cluster performance

baseline.value: Limited AAP support has been provided to UNICEF-led clusters and AoRs in 4-5 crises, but this has not been systematic

target.value: 2021:At least 12 UNICEF clusters/AoRs integrating common AAP approaches

title.narrative: # of global strategic partnerships for system-wide surge capacity on AAP/CCE

baseline.value: None currently exist, but work underway with existing stand-by partners to expand their AAP/CCE rosters

target.value: 2021:Requests for AAP/CCE support met by standby partners

actual.value: 2019:All UNICEF Standby partners have been consulted on the need to strengthen surge capacity to support collective approaches to AAP and community engagement

title.narrative: # of priority HAC COs and UNICEF clusters supported (remote, mission, learning, and/or surge) by EMOPS to implement AAP /CCE capacity building for local actors

target.value: 2021:At least 10 HAC COs/UNICEF Clusters/AoRs have initiated AAP capacity development initiatives
